newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian bourse watchdog calls meeting on Olivetti.
newsitem.headline: Italian bourse watchdog calls meeting on Olivetti.

text.p: Italian bourse watchdog Consob has called a meeting in Rome on Thursday with former Olivetti director general Renzo Francesconi and "the legal representative" of the group, news agency ANSA reported.
No one was available at Consob's Milan or Rome offices to confirm the report although Olivetti was expected to make a statement later on Wednesday.
No time was given for the meeting.
Francesconi resigned earlier on Wednesday, within a day of the stepping down of Olivetti chairman Carlo De Benedetti.

ANSA quoted a Consob spokesman as saying the meeting had been called to obtain "explanations as to the situation which has been created following the resignation of Francesconi and his declarations about the half year data released yesterday."
Olivetti released its half year results for 1996 at the same time as announcing De Benedetti's resignation. It made a 440.2 billion lire pretax loss.
Francesconi was quoted as saying that Olivetti's future looked very difficult and he did not agree with some results released.
Francesco Caio, managing director of the troubled information technology group, said he was surprised both at the content and form of Francesconi's statements.

"The figures at June 30 1996 have a strict accounting base and contain provisions which reflect in a correct and considered fashion evaluations in relation to strategic business decisions and the restructuring carried out by the company," Caio said.
"We have chosen the method of transparency and clarity which we can only confirm," Caio said.
The Consob spokesman said the markets division of the stock market commission "is evaluating the situation" with regard to any possible action on the share on the bourse.
He said a decision would be taken after a statement requested from Olivetti and expected later.
